name: Anonymous
com:
How to roll dice: "dice+2d6" without the quotes in the email field rolls 2d6. "dice+5d42+23" rolls 5d42+23. "noko+dice+2d6" rolls 2d6 without showing the roll in the email field.

In the rules department, you can look at http://www.4chan.org/rules - all global and board specific rules are in full effect. Apart from that, only two rules are important.

1. BE EXCELLENT TO EACH OTHER.
2. PARTY ON, DUDES. (AND DUDETTES)

>What is Exalted?
An epic high-flying role-playing game about reborn god-heroes in a world that turned on them.
Start here:http://theonyxpath.com/category/worlds/exalted/

>That sounds cool, how can I get into it?
Read the 3e core book (link below). For mechanics of the old edition, play this tutorial:http://mengtzu.github.io/exalted/sakuya.html
It’ll get you familiar with most of the mechanics.

>Gosh that was fun. How do I find a group?
Roll20 and the Game Finder General here on /tg/. good luck

name: Chronicler
com:
Writing General: 'Fanfiction' edition.

Welcome to /wg/, the thread for all /tg/ related writing. Whether you're plotting your campaign, trying to come up with a character backstory, or just trying to write some setting fluff, this is the place to post it. You don't even have a campaign, just an idea you want to develop? You're welcome here. While the rest of /tg/ is arguing over mostergirl mating and which way rivers are supposed to flow, we're here to help you turn your thoughts into an actual finished product.

As the successor to the Storythreads, we're also open to /tg/ related fanfiction (D&D, Warhammer, Battletech, whatever). In fact, if you've written any vaguely /tg/-related short stories, you can try them out here. We also have flash-fiction challenges from time to time.

There's a discord for writers here
https://discord.gg/6AwKHGF

The previous thread can still be found in the archive here
>>86799881

And finally an archive of /tg/ fiction can be found here:
http://1d4chan.org/wiki/Storythread

Are the Perks and Natural Talents hard numbers of where you'll be at over the course of the centuries you'll live as you pass through the realms or are you able to dedicate some of your older years to learning to be a bad ass alchemist?', 'time': 1670759825, 'resto': 86994915}, {'no': 86996107, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)07:08:35', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86996061
Natural Talents aren't really gonna grow. They represent your starting aptitude for things. Someone with 0 int can still learn but they simply won't be as good at learning as someone with 5.
With Perks, you could technically attain them all later in life but I assume that would be more the 1st level of most. The 2nd level are the kind genius that defines history so I'm not sure that could really be learned. Same as with Int, you can still do Alchemy and be plenty competent in it (especially with relevant stats), but I imagine it could never be as relatively effortless as the 2nd level.

Tell us about your horror settings, games, etc. Share inspirational art, prompts, etc.

>List of games:
Call of Cthulhu, Chill, Cold and Dark, Degenesis, Delta Green, Don't Rest Your Head, Dread, Esoterrorists/Fear Itself+Book of Unremitting Horror, Fall of Delta Green, GORE, Into The Shadows, KULT, Little Fears, Mothership RPG, Nemesis (free on Arc Dream's website), Nights Black Agents, Silent Legions (Mostly for the tables), Stalker: The SciFi RPG, Symbaroum, Ten Candles, Trail of Cthulhu, Unisystem (All Flesh Must Be Eaten, Witchcraft, Conspiracy X, etc.), Unknown Armies, The Whispering Vault, Vaesen

>Inspirational stuff:
Caitlin R Kiernan, Castlevania, Doom Watch, Fear & Hunger, George Romero, Ghostwatch, House of Leaves, I Am In Eskew, John Carpenter, Kolchak the Nightstalker, Laird Barron, John Langan, M.R. James, Nick Cutter, Old Gods of Appalachia, Quatermass, Ramsey Campbell, Remedy Series (Alan Wake, Control), SCP Foundation, Scarfolk Council, Shaun Hutson, Silent Hill, Stand Still Stay Silent, The Evil Dead, The Magnus Archives, The Secret World, The Stone Tapes, Anatomy, Thomas Ligotti, Twin Peaks, Vault of Evil forums, toomuchhorrorfiction

Other News:
Degenesis is currently free on the sixmorevodka website V4.
https://degenesis.com/

Shiva, Open Your Eye
https://www.nightmare-magazine.com/fiction/shiva-open-your-eye/

[{'no': 86994250, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)00:20:32', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994066
You only roll the highest sanity loss.', 'time': 1670736032, 'resto': 86934469}, {'no': 86995453, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)04:53:45', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994066
You roll what causes the highest SAN loss.', 'time': 1670752425, 'resto': 86934469}, {'no': 86995802, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:08:39', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Do you use any of these entities in your games, /hsg/?', 'filename': 'Lovecraftian Bestiary', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 1280, 'h': 1792, 'tn_w': 89, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670756919523530, 'time': 1670756919, 'md5': 'f/muHGjAhulo41RFvTkOUA==', 'fsize': 434942, 'resto': 86934469}, {'no': 86995981, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:42:55', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'One of the things that makes DG smoother to run for me than CoC is that it has a really good justification for the concept of the party as a unit. Oneshots in CoC are fine to just have a bunch of strangers but a lot of the justifications there are in the book feel very 'adventurer' in their reasoning. They take jobs or are part of a guild or some other such thing. How would you handle it if you wanted to run a chain of un/loosely connected oneshots with the same cast? Preferably without typecasting the character concepts too hard.', 'time': 1670758975, 'resto': 86934469}, {'no': 86996105, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)07:08:04', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995981
You start to bend credulity/go into monster of the Week or monster mash territory by the very nature of running one shot strings, but if you can get past that, you could either go for a patron (someone like a debunker or a weird occult dilettante) who hires everyone to run around. Trail of Cthulhu has the Armitage Enquiry campaign frame, which basically has you as roving investigators attached to miskatonic looking into the unnatural. Before Delta Green, pagan published a supplement called golden dawn, that had players as members of that occult society, you could model a player group off of something like that. Spiritualism, fringe religion and the occult have always had a following and wax and want in popularity, if your running CoC in the twenties or thirties, a group of people getting together for specifically spiritual, ritual or occult purposes isn't too outre.', 'time': 1670760484, 'resto': 86934469}]

name: Anonymous
com:
Fundamental Forces Edition

Welcome to /wbg/, the official thread for the discussion of in-progress settings for traditional games.

Here is where you go to present and develop the details of your worlds such as lore, factions, magic and ecosystems. You can also post maps for your settings, as well as any relevant art (either created by you or used as inspiration for your work). Please remember that dialogue is what keeps the thread alive, not asking questions to OP every third hour.

Last Thread: >>86797171

Resources for Newfags: https://sites.google.com/view/wbgeneral/
Worldbuilding links: https://pastebin.com/JNnj79S5
https://cryptpad.fr/pad/#/2/pad/view/Eo+fK41FKVR7xDpbNO0a0N4k0YYxrmyrhX3VxnM14Ew/
Fantasy map generator: https://watabou.itch.io/medieval-fantasy-city-generator

Thread Questions:

>What are the fundamental underlying forces of your setting? Did you go with picture related or something else?
>Did you add or change any of the forces?
>Are there any technologies, magic, or other kinds of powers able to manipulate these forces in your setting? If so, how do they work?
>How do you handle elements? Do you prefer the classical elements, chemical elements, or a mix of both?
>Finally, if there are any entities that embody these forces or elements? If so, what are they like?

com: How come you never see anyone come up with the idea of making a monk who's actually a GREGORIAN monk, not an Asian kung fu monk?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86995598, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)05:22:46', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995585
Then make it, if it's interesting. Come on, do it, faggot.', 'time': 1670754166, 'resto': 86994569}, {'no': 86995750, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)05:59:03', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'What is a Gregorian monk? I haven't heard of them.
Anyway, playing a monk of one of the nerd dork orders like St Benedict would be pretty hard unless you worked with the GM to work your order into the story. Like if your abbey's power was threatened or if your abbot's nephew at court had stumbled upon a dark secret and needed the best theological mind in his team.
Playing a monk based on one of the cool orders or especially one of the heretical and revolutionary orders like the Franciscans or Dulcinians would be pretty easy. They're mendicants, so they wander about. A heretical monk could be part of the wider setting's revolution background, or maybe they lost and now they're desperately hiding their past and the party offers them some hope of staying hidden. They're not a "real" monk, but nobody they meet knows that.

As for what to do in combat, I don't think that's necessarily an issue. You could just...not be a pacifist. Like Robin Hood has Friar Tuck, who is literally named after his sword. Or if you're not playing D&D there's plenty of things you can probably do in combat which aren't fighting. Having a character who's hell bent on preventing bloodshed is actually very useful.', 'time': 1670756343, 'resto': 86994569}, {'no': 86995806, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:09:16', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994569
I've seen that a couple of times.', 'filename': 'tes_oblivion_monk', 'ext': '.png', 'w': 297, 'h': 456, 'tn_w': 81, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670756956133259, 'time': 1670756956, 'md5': 'L2ykiVDM0ptZZso5KpWnew==', 'fsize': 76830, 'resto': 86994569}, {'no': 86995850, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:19:53', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Considered having a Christian styled monk as a playable character in a game-book I was going to write.
I always liked the idea of the humble old monk being more like a detective/scientist/bard. His main weapons being that he knows the ins and outs of everything. He knows which plants to eat and which to rub in. He'd knows what monsters are weak or immune to. He can Identify artifacts and potions and poisons. Also the power of persuasion and being able to turn a phrase.

All great if you don't play a setting that can just scream "LOL MAGE GO A BRA KEBAB BRA" or some other flavour of magicing away all problems.', 'time': 1670757593, 'resto': 86994569}, {'no': 86996069, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:58:16', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995528

name: Anonymous
com:
Vermin of valour edition
Previous thread: >>86941998

>What is /awg/?
A thread to talk about minis and games which fall between the cracks, or peoples' homebrew wargames. The >>>/tg/hwg thread doesn't entertain fantasy (for good reason) and the other threads are locked to more specific games.
This thread isn't tied to a game, a publisher, or a genre, let's just talk about fun wargames. Any scale, any genre, any company, any miniatures. Skirmishers welcome. Rules designers welcome.

>Examples of games that qualify
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_miniature_wargames

I thought you could activate quick spells from the hand.', 'time': 1670756469, 'resto': 86940532}, {'no': 86995767, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:01:45', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995764
Only during your turn', 'time': 1670756505, 'resto': 86940532}, {'no': 86995853, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:20:42', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995764
Quickplay spells can be activated from your hand during your turn, or from the field when it's been Set. When you Set it, keep in mind that it functionally becomes like a trap card and cannot be activated that turn -- this is a trait unique to Quickplay spells, which Normal, Continuous, and Field spells don't share.

Runick are an exception to this rule. Their field spell allows you to activate their quickplay spells from the hand on either player's turn.', 'time': 1670757642, 'resto': 86940532}, {'no': 86996051, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:55:17', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995722

If you were to make good Skaven you'd have to change some pretty significant parts of their culture & anatomy. The two driving factors for Skaven is hunger and warpstone.

Warpstone is dangerous destructive stuff and mutative and deadly to those not touched by the ruinous powers. While all the lore keeps saying things like "perhaps" and "could be" when talking about the link, it's pretty obvious that GW is just being coy. Skaven are born of the ruinous powers and crave it like drug addicts. In theory I think you could ween them off of it in an environment of absolute detox away from chaos with a long road of a behavioural breeding program since we can say freaks among them are able to show faint glimmers of moral virtue like Queek or the adviser rat from TW2.

From there even if you manage to pull it off you'd have an entire race of essentially AA members about Chaos with the emotional outlook of a dog since anything other then being a sniveling lovey dovey sap gets their ass killed for generations.

But more importantly than that is their hunger. Skaven cities have two sizes: Empty and Overpopulated. The little buggers breed so quickly that they invariably overload the local area's food production. Even when you 'clean up' the species and make females be something other than coked up baby factories, you're still having litters of a dozen or so per female per year. That's explosive growth.

So if you were to have "Good" Skaven, they would need really, really strict discipline among their ranks to keep these two downsides in check. Especially the breeding problem. They'd either need to live in such shitty places that outside forces balances their numbers, or they'd have to impose (or be imposed with) harsh controls on breeding and birth to keep their numbers under control. If nothing else it could be an interesting little fanfic to run this as a kind of prompt to an experiment or story.', 'filename': '9F83EBF2-C424-4B4A-B88C-BBB1A5BC11F2', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 810, 'h': 589, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 90, 'tim': 1670759651177601, 'time': 1670759651, 'md5': '67D5Mud1Qt5Q+oUOdmBMgw==', 'fsize': 124747, 'resto': 86988340}]

It's why they're the same people who think orcs are a stand-in for black people, revealing their own racism which they then project onto everything else instead to cope.', 'time': 1670756898, 'resto': 86994905}, {'no': 86995859, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:21:50', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994934
>>86995115
Sorry but thats retarded.
The reason Drizzt was interesting is because he came from a race that was always evil.
It made his struggle against his culture and his nature all the more interesting.

In fact the Realms had multiple examples of creatures or PCs that were exactly that.

>>86994905
You want to real reason or the pretend reason?
The real reason they hate it is because the woke ghouls hate the thought of objective, irredeemable evil existing, wokeism after all is an all ideology about making yourself feel better through attention from others while doing nothing yourself. That childmurderer over there? Oh he is just misunderstood, he had a rough childhood, you would be childmurderer too if you lived in a black ghetto.
Its basically the whole "nature vs nurture"-thing regurgitated for umpteenth time.
So an evil race cannot exist, you can only be evil due to being a victim of your badwrong environment.
Which is extra ironic because their whole outlook on people completely removes personal choice.', 'filename': 'Lysenkoism', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 600, 'h': 400, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 83, 'tim': 1670757710965756, 'time': 1670757710, 'md5': 'KXLbOFK/FEAQ415C6REdSg==', 'fsize': 67173, 'resto': 86994905}, {'no': 86996005, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:46:35', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995859
Being born into tougher circumstances very obviously increases the chances that you'll end up doing very bad things. Just as being born into very privileged circumstances very obviously increases the chance you'll end up thinking of yourself as superior and doing bad things that are more financial or political rather than physical, because those are the means available to you. Which isn't to say either of these groups have no choice and never produce people who do good, but it's moronic to suggest the circumstances they were born into don't have a huge impact on their prospects and the people they'll grow up to be. Someone that grows up in an ongoing war is going to be more comfortable with war and death than someone who isn't, for example. Which is used in militaristic fantasy cultures all the time.

No-one thinks a child murderer shouldn't be dealt with and shouldn't be reviled for their actions. The point is, obviously, that just punishing people or blaming their ancestry is useless in the long run, you need to remedy the cause.

When it comes to orcs though, I don't have any problem with it if an evil deity makes evil beings to do his evil work, that isn't bioessentialism or whatever, that's someone making something evil on purpose, these beings have no choice at all. Even if the orcs are naturally occurring beings, they could simply have a different moral compass than humans. Different species wired differently. To them, raiding might not be considered immoral, they might just see it as a normal part of life.

Directly applying a human mindset to fictional beings is stupid, unless the writers have written them as having a mindset like humans.', 'time': 1670759195, 'resto': 86994905}]

name: Anonymous
com:
Big Haul Edition

>What is Genesys?
Released in November 2017, Genesys is a pen-and-paper generic/universal RPG system and toolkit by Fantasy Flight Games and EDGE Studio, using a refined version of the system presented by their Star Wars RPGs (Edge of the Empire, Age of Rebellion, Force and Destiny). Its central mechanic is the Narrative Dice System, using pools made of specialized dice to create narrative results. The intention is for the system to be a highly flexible narrative system, adaptable to most any conceivable setting and premise.
https://www.fantasyflightgames.com/en/products/genesys/
https://edge-studio.net/

((LATEST NEWS))
>EDGE Studio is currently prioritizing digital releases so as not to be held up by more difficult physical releases
>"Twilight Imperium: Embers of the Imperium," a new space opera splat based on Twilight Imperium, is set to launch by the end of 2022
https://edge-studio.net/games/embers-of-the-imperium/
https://edge-studio.net/news-embers-of-the-imperium/

>Where can I find the books?
Check the Online Extras pastebin below for something useless. The core book is the only mandatory book.

com:
Welcome to the Old School Renaissance General, the thread dedicated to TSR-era D&D, derived systems, and compatible content.

Broadly, OSR games encourage a tonal and mechanical fidelity to Dungeons & Dragons as played in the game's first decade—less emphasis on linear adventures and overarching meta-plots and a greater emphasis on player agency.

If you are new to the OSR, welcome! Ask us whatever you're curious about: we'll be happy to help you get started.

last_replies:
[{'no': 86995495, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)05:01:13', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994662
Be master of at least 5 magicks
Do some serious rituals
Make some heavy sacrifices
Ascend
?profit', 'time': 1670752873, 'resto': 86994662}, {'no': 86995792, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:06:08', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994662
First we have to define lichdom.
>Eternal life powered by human souls
If we use that definition, Father from Fullmetal Alchemist is a lich.
>Magic undead
This one is more broad.

Once you have a definition you can build from there.
Going by our first one, you just need a way of gathering and storing a lot of souls for later consumption. You will need a lot of sacrifices, a receptacle and a way to feed from it.
For the second one, you just need to die but prevent your soul from leaving your body, or just being risen and taught magic

Once you have the checklist of things required to acquire/maintain lichdom, you add some extra restrictions and/or make some of the ingredients a byproduct of the ritual/spell, and you're done.', 'filename': 'latest-3344519798', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 955, 'h': 1342, 'tn_w': 88, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670756768663625, 'time': 1670756768, 'md5': '/pgnCR+K4d8It4vRxYLVgQ==', 'fsize': 316053, 'resto': 86994662}, {'no': 86995973, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:42:11', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994662

name: Anonymous
com:
The landwhale CEO of Wizards of the Coast said earlier this week that they have not been monetizing their D&D player base as much as they could, "we would like more share of your wallet" said Dr Cox (I may be mis-attributing the quote, but that's the quote).

Earlier in the year WotC said the future of D&D is online and in 2023 there is going to be a new D&D movie (which, I'm sure will be a disaster of identity politics).

Cynthia (the CEO) seems to have even read the wikipedia definition of what Magic the Gathering is, suggesting that she has no idea what the products she's in charge of even are.

So, /tg/, What do you think? Will WotC be successful in moving pen and paper to online only? D&D Beyound is a useful tool for character creation but not for running a campaign. Reading Physical Books on my tablet or laptop is a massive nuissance.

There are literally hundreds of other TTRPG options for people to play and dozens that are better. But none with the brand recognition of D&D.

If WotC is successful with nickel and diming their D&D players is there any hope for this hobby in the future?

I think I'll be playing L5R, ASOIF, Traveler or Burning Wheel, desu.

The stated goal is basically an attempt to make a Mercedes Lackey-style fantasy setting, so less on the grimdark and more on the faeries and frilly dresses. That said, it's still got an evil necromancer kingdom and whatnot.

Incidentally, it's not a bad setting; I played a Blue Rose game in high school with the Weird Library Girls (tm).

name: Anonymous
com: What does /tg/ think about this book? Have you ever used it as inspiration or in campaigns?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86995181, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:55:57', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994989
It was okay. It doesn't go too deep into the definition of evil, as generally speaking D&D takes the objective straightforward approach. And the general equipment is kinda lack luster (there is very little opportunity to use torture equipment in game, for example.) The prerequisite class were also kinda too demon themed, and I had a hard time fitting it in my campaign setting (although the Ur-priest is kinda neat, and the blood drinker and soul eater is good edgelord shit).

It did have like Drugs and Parasites you could take or equip to get more power with consequence which is rare in D&D 3.5, and I like the theme/trope of power at all cost. So those were the more practical shit I added in my game.

The feats were half cringe material, and half fucking hilarious (see pic); great read.

Monster and Spell list is in general meh.', 'filename': 'The use of female pronouns aged like wine', 'ext': '.png', 'w': 745, 'h': 172, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 28, 'tim': 1670748957411933, 'time': 1670748957, 'md5': '+4sVlGyK/wTAJYBdT3QJJg==', 'fsize': 37636, 'resto': 86994989}, {'no': 86995332, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)04:26:04', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995181
Based

>>86994989
I have used the vile spells in a campaign. Our groups sorcerer was getting corrupted and slowly gained access to these spells as 'bonus' magic on top of his normal allocation but every use gained him corruption. It worked quite well, the spells were obviously evil in nature so the rest of the party could see it and get some 'concerned mates' type roleplay in. He gave it up and destroyed the item corrupting him in the end (Accidentally annihilating the soul that was housed in it but it was the soul of a bad guy so fuck him.).', 'time': 1670750764, 'resto': 86994989}, {'no': 86995956, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:39:32', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'eh', 'time': 1670758772, 'resto': 86994989}]

name: Anonymous
com: How the fuck do you guys prepare content for your sessions? I keep getting told that railroading players is bad and thus I shouldn't prepare encounters but if I don't prepare encounters everything feels really shallow and incoherent. What are your guys' methods for preparing your sessions?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86995456, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)04:54:00', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995305
>railroading players is bad and thus I shouldn't prepare encounters
You're retarded and don't understand basic things people are telling you. Learn English or something.', 'time': 1670752440, 'resto': 86995305}, {'no': 86995627, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)05:30:14', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995305
>I keep getting told that railroading players is bad and thus I shouldn't prepare encounters
Whoever told you that was a fucking idiot. Of course you prepare encounters. You should also be able to quickly come up with some minor encounter should events transpire in a way that you couldn't foresee. But yes, prepare. Depends entire on what actual fucking game you are playing. If it's a dungeon crawler, then prepare the rooms. If it's a murder mystery, then add clues, hints and NPCs to interact with. If it's a heist, then prepare the building they break in etc.
Sometimes railroading isn't so bad. Some players aren't that actively thinking for themselves, they need to be pulled into the direction of the adventure.', 'filename': '1511366243732', 'ext': '.png', 'w': 700, 'h': 528, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 94, 'tim': 1670754614203980, 'time': 1670754614, 'md5': 'bLKXAurDO62a2oKk0aZQHA==', 'fsize': 322872, 'resto': 86995305}, {'no': 86995668, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)05:41:18', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995305
"Railroading bad" is the biggest /tg/ meme, parroted by niggers who never played a game in their entire life and thinks everyone playing should be a genius improv actor, an absolute system master and a professional game designer at the same time. Don't listen to what /tg/ says about tabletop games, same as you don't listen to /mu/ on music, /a/ on anime, /tv/ on movies or /v/ on video games.', 'time': 1670755278, 'resto': 86995305}, {'no': 86995901, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:29:09', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995305
an example of poor GMing I experienced that's somewhat similar to your picture
>low level adventure
>GM gives no input for what sort of characters we should make
>we make a book mobile troupe who travel around with a coach filled with books to sell
>You are about 20 minutes from the nearest city when you see a dragon attack it!
>we turn around and leave
>No, you can't do that. You have to go into the city
>Can you just have the dragon attack once we're already in the city?
>No
If you have something planned out, you can always give your players some guidance in character creation. If not they might just do something wacky that doesn't fit with what you've come up with.
Once character creation is said and done and you're planning for the next session, you can always just plan around their wacky characters. There's nothing wrong with asking your players what their plans are for their characters so you know what they're probably going to do next session.', 'time': 1670758149, 'resto': 86995305}, {'no': 86995922, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)06:33:36', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86995305
Improvise, retard.', 'time': 1670758416, 'resto': 86995305}]

com:
This is a general for everything 3D printed relating to /tg/ from sci-fi, fantasy, historicals, fantasy football, and more! Share your printed minis, terrain, print fails, 3d modeling, printing advice, works in progress, or anything else /tg/-related to 3D printing.

>DO:
- Post pics of your prints be they fails or triumphs
- Keep your prints and files about tabletop games only
- Encrypt file links
- Use Passwords
- Post your resin/printer/settings for faster advice
- Help your fellow anons with advice

>TRY TO:
- Not make a new thread until old one dies
- Not encourage namefags, tripfags, fumefags and coomers
- Not spoonfeed newfags
- Not encrypt links to websites
- Not discuss encryption/passwords
- Keep your model pics naked (no paint/undercoat only)
- Look after small artists/studios
- Buy something from or tip an artist/studio you like
- Read the last 3 threads before posting

[{'no': 86995011, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:13:13', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994974
...also, nice pics.', 'time': 1670746393, 'resto': 86994747}, {'no': 86995167, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:52:40', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994780
Orc behavior during the siege of Avignon:
>Part 1: The city is secured. While the siege lasted years, the melee for the city itself takes about a week at most. Civilian casualties are light with very few dying as the Greenskins focus on the enemy.
>Part 2: the city gets sacked. This lasted about three days. Civilian casualties are massive as the Orcs take out their rage on the peasantry. Most of the men are massacred, but the women are defiled by the victorious Orcs who make a game out of it. The city intelligentsia are killed to a man with academics and priests suffering the worst fates: while Orcs mostly sated their bloodlust with the peasants, the Burghurs were left to his Lieutenants who preferred the art of flaying. Nobles, unless they came upon a particularly attractive one or an intellectual, were taken hostage and ransomed which helped fund the campaign.
>Part 3: the symbolic destruction. The city's catacombs, tombs, graves, mausoleums, were all exhumed with the remains thrown into the open. Piles of bones were made in the graveyards as their mortal remains were looted by the victorious conquerors. A pyramid of skulls, those of the bravest noblemen, was stacked in front of the city gates: a reminder to those who still resisted the Empire. The great libraries of the universities, the magic academy, the cathedral schools, and others were torn open with the books being burnt or dumped into the river whose water turned black with ink.
Other things were noted: the intentional avoidance of Gnomish businesses. It has been theorized that the Gnomish Elders cracked a deal with the Emperor to avoid his wrath but judging by the fact that their businesses were seized without compensation as soon as the war was over, they were either intentionally put up as a scape goat or were the suckers of the century.
-Jon Connington: the Military Revolution, Page 247, paragraph 7', 'filename': '0ba2da206294a6a5f3de1eb99ced41a8', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 1104, 'h': 617, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 69, 'tim': 1670748760306201, 'time': 1670748760, 'md5': 'Q5a+8hrSIyYgQ1Ub4QhdwQ==', 'fsize': 115551, 'resto': 86994747}, {'no': 86995516, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)05:05:31', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Our new neighbors are Urukian-Gondorians. >Hides in places like offices and schools.
>Slowly feed off of human memories. Draining people I'm the area of memories slowly. By the time anyone notices proper are already missing years of their lives.
>When a human is fully drained they incubate a new flesh drinker in their body, to impersonate them for awhile, and then burst out to continue the cycle.
>They don't actually kill. Even those who they incubate people in live on afterwards as broken shells of themselves.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>>DRAWTHREAD RULES<<<

>Requesters:
• Provide good, detailed references (pictures are better than verbal descriptions), so the artists know what you're looking for.
• Only bump your request once every 24 hours. Don't bump WIPs.
• If you have a WIP quote the Anchor Post, and attach the WIP so your drawfag can find you.
• Do not reply to other deliveries with a request that the artist fill your request next, this is called 'piggybacking'.
• Do not make multiple requests in the same thread and do not serially request multiple characters after a delivery. Suggesting several concepts for artists to choose from counts as making multiple requests.
• If you're unsatisfied with your completed request, please wait at least one week before you re-request. If someone follows this rule, don't waste posts by complaining about it.
• Reminder that nobody is entitled to a delivery under any circumstances within these threads. Don't critique others' requests. If you don't like it, don't draw it.
• Stay on topic. This thread has been deleted twice!

>Artists and Artists-to-Be:
• Feel free to drop your tumblrs/websites/commission/etc information, but if you're dropping your commission info, please consider filling a request beforehand instead of just advertising.

Drawfags open for commissions:

name: Anonymous
com:
previous thread: >>86804700

<<<<<<<< READ THE PDF BEFORE ASKING WHERE TO START

GURPS is a modular, adaptable system, capable of running a wide range of characters, settings, and play styles with level of detail varying from lightweight to completely autistic.
Optional rules allow you to emulate different genres with a single system, even switching genres within a single game.

A nearly complete archive of GURPS books can be found by those who pay attention to file extensions.
Never post direct links to the archive anywhere.

If you're wondering where to start:
The Basic Set covers everything, including a lot of optional rules you probably won't use.
A genre guide can be found in the archive, under Unofficial > GURPSgen. It tells you what extra books and articles you may find useful for many common genres.
How To be a GURPS GM is a good read even for players.
GCS (gurpscharactersheet.com) is an excellent character builder software with page references to all the books and the option to export to both Foundry and Fantasy Grounds.

TQ: Will AI art really save GURPS artwork problem?

>God of evil dragons, with several different methods of expressing that in enough settings that you can pretty much 'pick your model' and use it; it's hard to fuck up though
>Fantastic variety of servants; it's actually harder to narrow down standard fantasy baddies who wouldn't look out of place with some evil dragon iconography; you could put evil nobles, social climbers, goblins, some varieties of undead, inhuman dragon hybrids, demons AND devils, actual dragons, ect all in one room
>Seriously on paper it's Tiamat's cult which would resemble the local fantasy equivalent of the Legion of Doom if played straight
>Multiple major modules basically revolving around her and her cult
>If you want her to be Lawful or Chaotic evil, it's genuinely up to you depending on which version you're using (and, in settings like Ebberon, you could make the case that her heads have different domains/alignments)
>Can either be a bitchin five-headed dragon, arguably one of the most iconic concepts DnD ever contributed to fantasy, or a hot chick in standard 80's spiky fantasy armor
>Indirectly made Kobolds', 'filename': 'e7c359bff7f61988c256c72709c8b719', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 1080, 'h': 1080, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670737293230113, 'time': 1670737293, 'md5': 'CQ5oxJ5tG1OF2L6eVeaTSQ==', 'fsize': 247274, 'resto': 86992624}, {'no': 86994968, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:02:23', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Classic demon or dragon or whatever. Objectively, Absoutely not. Big Waaagh is just strictly better than KB since most of the KB allegiance abilites suck and the only one that's notably good is ALSO in big Waaagh. As for getting dominion, I'd definitely get one whole if you can since they're going for around a hundred bucks and you can semi-regularly find them for 80-90, and it gets you the KB half AND the Stormcast half and most importantly, the core rules of the game (Which is 60 bucks on its own). Be prepared to convert though if you stick with snagging dominon bits, as the gutrippaz in that do NOT come with musicians or banner holders and you really want those in your units. If you get the Xmas box it solves the issue of the musician at least, since you can just make the rippaz that come in the box with spears too, build both the drum AND the horn option, and swap one of the dominion spears for a musician, but you'll still need to convert a banner bearer. I haven't mentioned it because I don't want to shill but here.

The game is currently in a state where it has two different versions to cater to different styles of play, basically because of my tastes in tabletop games.. I have sat down and worked on both to make sure they both have a good degree of quality and are upkept. They both also now have Google sheets. You can find them here. Karda is the original experience, with lower stats, tougher checks, and a more down to earth feel, whereas Mohi is geared towards slightly stronger characters with higher power levels.

As of now unless a new set of masks has been made canon in the past year or so it's got all the masks in canon bar a few I think (Mutation is one I think that's not there? It's been a hot minute so I'm not sure).

https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1kHy5h1wMyjFXOmV656zLruSphkAYpBPK?usp=share_link

name: Anonymous
com:
I've seen people on the 40k /k/ thread claim that the way the imperium (and other factions) fight is retarded. Like how vehicles such as the bandeblade are just massive sitting ducks for missiles and bunker busters, and how they are impractical/stupidly designed.

Plus emphasis on retarded melee combat, where most factions (except perhaps the tau) are guilty of.

Can the imperium (or other faction) beat a modern army in a conventional battle? No WMDs like nukes, orbital bombardment or exterminatus shit.
last_replies:
[{'no': 86994902, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)02:48:44', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86984801
A lot of the impractical designs are because of space magic. We don't need giant super-weapons IRL because we don't blow up entire planets infested with millions (or billions) of hostile aliens. That doesn't factor in resources, either.

40k has technology that necessitates super-weapons, but has a hard limit to its availability. The main things are navigators and void shields. Navigators are what allow humans to traverse the warp, but they are few in number. It's why ships in 40k are huge and impractical. They're actually the smallest thing capable of warp travel using a single navigator. It would be better to have more smaller ships, but none of them would be usable.

Likewise, void shields are necessary in the far future where ships in orbit can bombard a planet's surface. Void shields are large and expensive, so they get put on the single largest weapons available. And those large weapons, titans, are limited by who can pilot them. It's a case of metagaming your opponent. They have giant ships in orbit, so you build giant robots on the ground, so they build giant tanks to kill the giant robots, and so on.

And none of this can be done with AI. In some cases, everything is completely analog.', 'filename': '1633333247074', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 1000, 'h': 1444, 'tn_w': 86, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670744924526238, 'time': 1670744924, 'md5': 'Oy9WPwyP1ywxhDZyd9httg==', 'fsize': 286380, 'resto': 86984801}, {'no': 86994952, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)02:58:49', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86984801
Complex computers and AI exist in the blur between extreme suspicion and blasphemy so most things have to be analog, that's what servitors are for. Guess you could wire a servitor into a missile to fly it like the grot bomb.

>Retarded melee
Strong armor, shields, and ways to avoid being shot are so prevalent that the best way to kill is melee. I think this is based on the force fields from dune; you had to get up close or board their ship because no ranged weapons could pierce them.', 'time': 1670745529, 'resto': 86984801}, {'no': 86995149, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:49:04', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86987595
Carbon dating puts her around 20.', 'time': 1670748544, 'resto': 86984801}, {'no': 86995201, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:58:39', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86986643
Magnus the Red and daemon princes aren’t just any random daemon. You’re comparing the absolute strongest out there to like little nurglins and bloodletters and shit.', 'time': 1670749119, 'resto': 86984801}, {'no': 86995337, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)04:27:38', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985165
Is that... text with space between it?
HELP ME YOTSUBAMAN IM GOING INSANE AAAAAAA', 'time': 1670750858, 'resto': 86984801}]

No.', 'time': 1670748724, 'resto': 86994695}, {'no': 86995177, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:54:41', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994695
Basically no. Frequent occurrences of unruly adventurers implies that 'adventurer class' people are common in the world (whether that means magic affinity or power level bullshittery), in which case they would've already been integrated into society and would be readily available to quash unruly adventurers. So what you have are vassaled knights and peasant militias (as >>86994877 explained) which in game terms are already composed of 'adventurer tier' individuals who can reasonably overwhelm party-sized incursions into their territory
tl;dr Adventurer Hunters as a distinct occupation make as little sense as an Adventurer Guild', 'time': 1670748881, 'resto': 86994695}, {'no': 86995312, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)04:21:00', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994695

My wife and I are looking for a tabletop RPG in the style of DnD that we could both play together. We don't want to switch hats midgame with the GM and we don't mind if we need to use an app.

Any good suggestions?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86994630, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)01:41:14', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86991475
I don't mean to be rude but your wife looks a little crabby', 'time': 1670740874, 'resto': 86991475}, {'no': 86994870, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)02:38:50', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Ironsworn and Starforged are pretty good. Avatar Legends and Fabula Ultima also seem pretty easy to take a 'JRPG' approach, where they control pre-written party members in combat + skill checks, GM does the roleplaying, but I haven't tried it. In general, you're going to be running 'main character' games. It's good to angle your concepts around things that are fairly solo or give them reasonable authority over a small group of people - this can even be the 'shot caller' in a group of friends.', 'time': 1670744330, 'resto': 86991475}, {'no': 86995109, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:36:19', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86991475
Not D&D-like, but a pretty good 2-player roleplaying game is Inhuman Conditions. Its basically about running a Voight-Kampff test from Blade runner, with one player playing the detective and the other a robot or human that is being interviewed. Ive played ot a bunch with my roomate amd its pretty fun, files are officially free online but you can buy a kinda expensive copy that comes with really nice components. Its quick, so worth a shot at the very least.', 'time': 1670747779, 'resto': 86991475}, {'no': 86995127, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)03:41:28', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86991475

name: Anonymous
com:
Hey there, everyone; how's it going? I've been working on a game called COGS over the past couple of years (a small number of people may even already know of it from a few threads I've posted it in). Yesterday, I launched a Kickstarter for it at https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/scribblegs/cogs-expanded-edition to fund a physical release filled with artwork and more supplemental material. It's got a small goal compared to some projects I've seen for FUCKING 5E SUPPLEMENTS, and a good chunk of the funding will probably go toward shipping and printing costs before anything else. However, I would appreciate any help that my fellow fa/tg/uys can provide by backing or spreading the word to people they feel might be interested.

>fuck your shill thread, faggot
Now I've been on /tg/ for a couple of years now; I perfectly get being mad about a shill thread and won't really object if I get called a faggot for it. However, I want to make clear that I would personally rather shill on 4chan and get called a fag than ever set foot on the unholy trash fire known as reddit.

>So where's the game then, gayboy?
I'm not a psychopath, don't worry. There is a free (or, well, PWYW at the moment) version of the game available on both DTRPG and itch.io at https://www.drivethrurpg.com/product/382321/COGS--Generic-Oneshot-Generala-System and https://scribblegs.itch.io/cogs, respectively. Unfortunately, the text is still choppy at times since I'm a single amateur writer with no editor. However, the plan for the free versions, whether the Kickstarter succeeds or fails, is to update them to match the expanded edition and make them entirely free (not PWYW). They would become the "basic" game version, with no artwork and little supplemental content (like character creation tips, example content, or establishing expected power levels). However, it would still feature what rules and extra content they already have (which is already enough to play a game).

1/2

name: Notepad Anon
com:
It's a Holy Jolly December, can we ever be redeemed? Welcome to the December thread of homebrew discussion on /tg/. This is part of my effort to get people discussing classic homebrew discussion and assist the board in general when it comes to their game design endeavors.

>Who is this namefaggot?
I'm just a dude who writes games and likes the homebrew discussions on /tg/. I frequent a few threads, but I'm just here to facilitate discussion. I was [BusinessMaxxing] in the UK last month, I'm back and scored some fackin' goals.

>Why should I homebrew?
/tg/ products are fairly unique in that it's actually pretty simple to make them these days, with a plethora of products to assist in making and playtesting your game. Making your own games helps understand why games are made the way they are, as well as being fun to do.

>What you should post
Ideas for games, games you're currently making, updates to your own games in broad strokes, and any homebrewing for existing products that don't get much attention. Discussion about the above is welcome. Post good, be good, and look over others products, they care if someone looks more than anything.

>Oh No! The Thread is Over!
Have no fear, the thread will resume at the first of every month. If you want to make another during the month, go for it. I can't, and won't, stop you. If you want to make a thread on your own game, go for it!
One suggestion: Don't add General to the name. Mid-Month Threads are "relatively" common.

>Resources for the aspiring developer
>https://anydice.com/ (A fantastic resource for checking probabilities)
>https://miro.com/ (A online whiteboard with tools to help organize yourself)
>https://www.notion.so/ (Similar to the above, but in a bit cleaner format for those who work in larger teams)
>https://rolz.org/ (Impromptu playtesting at its finest)
>https://www.youtube.com/user/georgephillies/playlists (Game Design Lectures)

1. A bulk of the rules were written with 1v1 in mind but the game can play up to 6 player. sub: Amateur Game Design and Homebrew Thread

name: Anonymous
com:
The basic premise is that humanity used to be a galaxy spanning empire, but some force has destroyed almost every human planet.
There are only nine human planets left now. Technically they're under one empire but realistically none of the planets are united. Each is basically its own isolated culture living under very sub-optimal conditions.
Something now threatens these nine planets.

The players aren't your traditional heros. They're some of the few people with ftl communication, and basically all they can do as a collective is communicate with eachtoher.
The game would be on a discord server and happen asynchronously, because that's almost exactly what the characters would be experiencing. They can only type so so can their players.
Most of the actual challenge is through weird logic puzzles, and negotiations with inhuman npcs.

Basically homestuck meets 40k. But I can't just lead with calling it that.

I'd like to make a good first impression on them with one, what would you suggest I run?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86994096, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)23:52:17', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86988673
>>86988879
>I don't wanna give them a bad time with terrible gm-ing or bad game design that's all
the only way to be a truly terrible GM is to be a dick or to know so little that you don't manage to do things without needing to spend >50% of the time being confused at players while telling them to shut up so you can look things up
game design is not a concern for people who have no experience with RPGs
Play something that lets you do stuff relevant to their interests that you find reasonably fun to play
D&D5e is easy to play but stupidly laid out and irritatingly fake-deep in design, but it's a jumping on point for many people because of being popular. Might be best avoided but if you're looking at a one-shot it's an easy option.
PBTA has, like, a billion things so you can find some shit they're into probably but GURPS lets you do whatever and has more depth, which you said you want
The FFG 40k RPG systems can be fun because the systems are extremely enmeshed in the setting and get people into it pretty solidly in my experience

The real question is what do your brothers expect from the experience?', 'time': 1670734337, 'resto': 86988673}, {'no': 86994288, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)00:32:22', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994096
>fake-deep in design
What does this even mean?', 'time': 1670736742, 'resto': 86988673}, {'no': 86994338, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)00:43:29', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86994288
It looks deep at first glance but doesn't achieve that depth in actual play.
There's a shitton of spells but many of them are straight up, down, or sidegrades of each other. Class abilities aren't much better most of the time.', 'time': 1670737409, 'resto': 86988673}, {'no': 86994392, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)00:54:28', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86988673
>I feel like something without even a little mechanical depth would just be a drama with dice.
thats what ttrpgs are', 'time': 1670738068, 'resto': 86988673}, {'no': 86994434, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)01:01:08', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86988673
Heroquest 2e/Questworlds. You have to have played a different game for it to irritate you. Other Worlds is a better version; uses d100 as the control die. All of the above are a few steps in complexity above Risus & FAE and are: fast, functional, flexible. Dead simple, fun customization, easy to brew/alter.

Supers! is the next step up, simple but standardized. Single die-type pools, fast and flexible, easy etc.

Cortex Prime/Marvel Heroic is also a simple flexible and consistent system. You’ll have to hack it a bit, but the system can take excessive strain.

After this point, things get more complicated. Mixing widely varying powers and levels starts breaking stuff…

The easiest d100 with simulated setting values is Frontier Space, a sci-fi game. Very consistent system and rules. I’ve never satisfactorily twisted it past the mid-superheroic level, but someone probably can.

Talislanta is the simplest consistent d20 system. As if modern DnD didn’t become a conflicting rules pile. Templates for damn near everything, restricted but very flexible magic.

D6 Legend is the next simplest single-type die pool game. Spawned multiple systems, ie Prowlers & Paragons. This is still simpler than DND, since these are mostly consistent systems.

Monsters & Magic is the simplest OSR that gives explicit narrative guidelines for green players. Incorporates newer mechanics, keeps the basic OSR structure. Castles & Crusades is a traditional equivalent, more heavily restricted RAW.

At this point, everything is still simpler than Fate. Past this point, player confusion increases, for some reason. Idk. This is the least complex set of games that allow for PC customization & remain dead easy to run. All of them can be run solely from the core books, aside from the OSR-ish — but the cores will give you simple conversions to use with MMs. All are located on /tg/. Enjoy.', 'filename': '6BB03342-B7BB-4EA2-BBF1-E28ADBE8320F', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 817, 'h': 1024, 'tn_w': 99, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670738468052202, 'time': 1670738468, 'md5': 'KH7vD6uMaGa4Pzhhnj97KA==', 'fsize': 285491, 'resto': 86988673}]

Does anyone have experience with using A.I. Generated art in tabletop rpgs?

Most of the attention nowadays is on 2d art, but I think the best use for this technology is in making text. It’s a quick way to generate lots of unexpected and original locations, descriptions, items, characters, etc.

But the 2d art could be good for generating quick references for characters and stuff too.

Anyways: ideas or thoughts on this stuff?

name: Anonymous
com:
How do you solve the trolley problem when it comes up in-game in some form? Do you desperately try to find another path that saves everyone? Do you make the choice to walk away?

Trolley problems can sometimes be subtle. The players and even the GM might not realize that the current situation qualifies as a trolley problem. Anything that involves choosing which people to save, or trading the well-being of one group for the well-being of a different group, could be a trolley problem.

What are some trolley problems you have encountered in actual games? How have you solved them?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86993544, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)22:34:48', 'name': 'Smaugchad', 'com': '>>86988243
Well, Soth is cast out of the Demiplane of Dread and the next Dragonlance product he was explicitly a part of was the Dragons of Summer Flame novel. Having a canonical major supporting character from Dragonlance as a Darklord was a source of contention in the fanbase during the 90s so I decided to tackle it directly.

Mordenkainen and Vecna also are part of the Ravenloft Canon with similarly contentious implications - Die Vecna Die can be used as a cataclysmic conclusion to the second edition.

I think that because it's a common fantasy trope for characters to just up and vanish from the known universe and Ravenloft was just such a place it was tempting for authors to dabble in "what they did while they were gone" type adventures while it still seemed fresh.', 'time': 1670729688, 'resto': 86974461}, {'no': 86994293, 'now': '12/11/22(Sun)00:33:42', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86989608

What you mention is close to what Warlock is in practice. Highly customizable magic user that can do a lot without having to use spell slots and can still cast high level spells.

Warlock fills the niche of 'caster, but different' while Sorcerers are just 'Wizards, but worse'. Especially now, when several Wizard subclasses are some of the strongest in the game with almost zero optimization necessary (Bladesinger, Divination, Chronurgy), while Sorcerers' best subclasses just make them catch up with other casters with regards to spell flexibility.

It's impossible to make any casting class better than Wizards since they're the best class but all other full casters at least manage to fill different niches.', 'time': 1670747467, 'resto': 86985781}]

name: Anonymous
com:
Every RPG that gives options for mixed martial/magical parties are either unbalanced or unsatisfying magically. Furthermore, the kinds of players who perfer playing mages over martials and the kinds of players who prefer playing martials over mages fundamentally want different tones for their games.

RPGs should be designed arround fully magical parties (e.g. Earthdawn), fully martial parties (e.g. every good Sword and Sorcery game), or parties where players each control a magical and a nonmagical character (e.g. Ars Magica)

name: Anonymous
com:
Does anyone else despise purely passive/reactionary abilities and skills? I mean the stuff that you can't do a single thing with until the GM explicitly prompts you to roll them. Every fucking system is riddled with this shit.
>health/endurance skill
>defense/dodge skill
>awareness skill
>social/mental resistance skill
It's like a tax on staying alive. I hate it. I make a point of dumping them as hard as possible in favor of skills that I can actually do stuff with. So what if my character dies? At least I got to do stuff while he was alive.
last_replies:
[{'no': 86980873, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)17:25:56', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86979586
Languages and tools from d&d 5e. Played for years, used them.. maybe once, I think.
> but that’s on the GM for not present opportunities for their use
Well that’s the point, isn’t it? The system doesn’t really have a clue what to do with the rule, so it offloads responsibility to the GM. That doesn’t mean they can’t or won’t find ways to incorporate them, but a system that’s conscious of its own procedures is less likely to have that kind of redundancy.

For an egregious example (that’s more in line with what I think OP is talking about), take perception-based skills; specifically 3e’s Spot and Listen. They’re separate from Search (which is the actually proactive one), and increase your chance of seeing or hearing traps/assassins/secrets - things that are entirely decided by the gm. And in fact, the gm is encouraged to make the roll for the player, to avoid the meta of knowing you rolled like shit. After character creation (not including any further improvements), the utility of those skills are entirely out of the players’ hands.

I totally get what the above is in aid of (verisimilitude), but without doing the smart thing and giving it an additional active use, it just feels like
> a tax on staying alive', 'time': 1670624756, 'resto': 86957059}, {'no': 86980987, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)17:39:37', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86968333
>"Chi ki chi ki ban ban"
>"Mmh - chi ki chi ki ban ban"
>5 women all singing chi ki chi ki ban ban

Songs for adventurers on the road?', 'time': 1670625577, 'resto': 86957059}, {'no': 86984714, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:29:21', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86957059
Passive skills are better because they reflect what your character IS, rather than what he CAN DO. Being too tough to cut with a sword is a better flex than being able to actively defend yourself with a shield. All active abilities turns the game into whack-a-mole, you either succeed or fail every time. You are objectively wrong to want only active abilities.', 'time': 1670653761, 'resto': 86957059}, {'no': 86989259, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)14:14:07', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86957059
You sound like a bitch', 'time': 1670699647, 'resto': 86957059}, {'no': 86993949, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)23:31:16', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86957059

name: Anonymous
com: At what point is it not a dick or fun ruining move to introduce consequences for violating the masquerade/other similar rules? It’s obviously overreacting for the feds to get involved over one report of what looked like someone drinking the blood of a hooker but what about a community all talking about how a group of teens saw a wolf walking on their hind legs?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86982733, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:17:03', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86978176
There should ALWAYS be consequences, just keep the consequences proportional.', 'time': 1670638623, 'resto': 86978176}, {'no': 86982806, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:25:10', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86980734
So, assuming you don't know your players very well: before their first session as vampires, ask them what they know of it or if they have any experience with it. During the game, tell them where the line is, how to fix it, and what the consequences are.

>a dick or fun ruining move
That's more about group dynamic and flow of play than about the masquerade. Generally, you want a player to be aware that a course of action might risk the masquerade (and what they'll have to clean up) before they commit to it.

If you're asking for what level of response suits what level of breach, I don't know. You could see if there's a WoD thread up.', 'time': 1670639110, 'resto': 86978176}, {'no': 86984656, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:22:32', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86978176
